bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Western Carolina Power Company, September 18, 1922

div1.p: Carter reports on his survey of mosquito breeding in certain portions of Bridgewater Lake and the surrounding area.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to the Western Carolina Power Company, September 18, 1922
div1.p:
Bridgewater (Sept/22)
CHARLOTTE, N. C.
Sept. 18, 1922. Western Carolina Power Company,
Charlotte, N. C.
Gentlemen:

I have the honor to submit this report of a survey
to determine mosquito breeding in certain portions of Bridgewater
Lake and in some of the breeding places, streams, marshes etc. in
its neighborhood, made during the four days Sept. 12th to 15th in-
clusive. This survey is a continuation of those made Aug. 16th
to 22nd, 1921 and July 17th and 18th of this year, and this report
is to be considered in connection with the other two.

item.p:
I must premise by saying, that the weather was exceed-
ingly unfavorable for land breeding of Anopheles--meaning the
breeding in streams, ponds, marshes etc. as distinguished from
pond-breeding. It was exceedingly dry, I was informed by many
farmers that there had been no rain for over four weeks and conse-
quently many marshes and small streams were dry and only permanent
collection of water were breeding Anopheles. Naturally the amount
of breeding on land of this kind then, was less than would have been found
under normal conditions, say two to three or four weeks earlier.
(1) THE JAMISON PLACE
Mrs. Hemphill occupies the house which she states was
occupied by Jamison last year. This is about 400 yards beyond
Nebo Station., up the valley from the station: on the ridge between
this valley and the next one.
(a) A pot-hole, not much larger than a wash tub, was
in the woods about 120 yards from the house, and to the west of it,
is breeding Anopheles profusely. Too small to be of much impor-
tance. There were evidently a series of these holes in a ravine the
others of which have dried up. All of them breeding would have
been of sanitary importance.
-2-
(b) West of the house, 200 to 250 yards in a good
sized pool at the intersection of the ravine with the branch
breeding Anopheles very profusely, all sizes; 100 larvae and
pupae taken.
(c) Two small eddies in this branch breeding freely.
Other eddies seen but not examined.
(d) Same branch as (b) and (c), at the junction with
another branch from the right, Anopheles breeding freely in
side pools and eddies, the same above this junction.
The larvae from these breeding places developed into
Anopheles punctipennis Sept. 13th 14th and 15th.
Of the above places (b) is of the greatest sanitary
importance on account of its position and the freedon of its
breeding.
(2) THE BOST HOUSE.
(a) Branch from the spring to the creek cleaned out.
Work very well done except some caving near the spring and
near the creek end. Not dipped but the latter place would pro-
bably be breeding Anopheles as it was doing so profusely last
year. It is only a very small area now, however. No S. C.
(b) The marsh across the creek from his house at the
bridge is also ditched and free from water, except a very
samll pool which is breeding tremendously. (a concentration
pool.) It is too small to be of any sanitary importance.
(c) The edges of the creek about the bridge below,
under and above, are breeding freely where the water is flowing
slowly and grass hangs down in it. This was not breeding last
year when the creek was high. This is of sanitary importance.
(3) LEWIS HOUSE (MRS. EDITH LEWIS AND SON).
This house is higher up the creek than Mr. Bost's
and on the other side of both the creek and railroad. It is,
roughly, one-quarter to one-third mile distance from Bost's and
probably 100 or 125 yards from Mrs. Weaver's house which is on
the same side of the railroad with it and just above it. This
place, Weaver's and Bost's are all close enough to be affected
-3-
by the breeding in the area around the old Mill race.
(a) A small branch from back of the Lewis house, just
below it, runs through the railroad. The lower portion of this
from the crossing to the main creek is breeding Anopheles
freely. (Dr. Boldridge examined this, I did not see it). A
large pool at the railroad, say 150 yards from the house, is
breeding Culex profusely, a few Anopheles, but not of sanitary
importance. It is evidently badly contaminated.
(b) The pools in and about the old mill race which
were breeding so profusely last year, are still breeding, but
very much less so. Some are entirely dried up and some are
scummed. Two only are breeding profusely. One good size and
one small. Those that are dried up have done so recently as
the ground is very boggy. Water rises in one's track as the
foot comes out of the mud.
(c) The creek itself is breeding, and breeding freely,
in every eddy and side pool around this place. On the grassy
banks and behind little hammocks. It is producing more than
the pools around the Mill race. This condition of breeding ex-
tends both up and down as far as we examined, say 100 feet
each way. The same condition was found above ((a): (b) & (c) - pages 3 & 4) & below ((c)
page 2): & doubtless extends more or less, up the each other.
These last places (a), (b) and (c) are none of them
more than 300 yards from the Lewis house and some of them less
than 200. The pools in the upperpart of the old mill race and
the breeding part of the creek are some 100 to 150 yards of the
Weaver house. These places are also close enough to Mr. Bost's
house to affect it, but less than they would the other two.
(C) MASON'S HOUSE, one-half mile more or less up
the creek from Mrs. Weaver's house, between creek and railroad;
about 50 yards from railroad.
(a) In the main creek just below the mouth of a small
branch is long back-water 30 to 40 feet, breeding profusely
about 300 yards from house and below the house.
-4-
(b) Same condition occurs in some eddies in the
creek a few yards, 30 to 40, above this place. All sizes and
pupae.
(c) Meadow at the angle of the creek and this branch
near the old sawdust pile, dry now, but evidenly marshy in or-
dinary weather. A few cat-tails, many bulrushes and the hollows
show bare; glazed; cracked surfaces. This place would be physi-
cally well suited for Anopheles breeding in the ordinary wet
weather of the summer.
(d) A creek, small, beyond Mr. Mason's house, say
60 yards, a few Anopheles near the crossing, but of no sanitary
importance and none further down. This creek higher up towards
the railroad is breeding freely or profusely, all sizes, where-
ever grass or other obstructions are down in the water or where
there is any little indentation of the bank. The total of this
breeding is large. It is from 100 to 200 yards from the house.
(e) The main creek above the house about the edge of
the cornfield 300 yards from the house is breeding moderately
or freely.
This creek would not breed -a would not head nimb- in wet weather. It runs too
freely. At that time, however, the marshes and small streams
now dry, would be physically suited for breeding and doubtless
be breeding.
(5) MISS CORA BRITTAIN'S HOUSE: About one-quarter
mile above Hendrix and probably one-third of a mile below Carswell's.
North side of railroad.
(a) Four Anopheles larvae taken in the spring. One
winged insect, Anopheles punctipennis, caught in barn. Spring about
40 or 50 yards from house, of no sanitary importance
(b) Branch runs down out of the pasture close by the
spring and house to the big creek. Presents many places physi-
cally well suited for breeding--pools, eddies etc., but has no
breeding of sanitary importance. Is very full of Dixa larvae
which is probably the reason for the absence of the Anopheles.
-5-
(c) The main creek, probably 300 or 350 yards from the house,
is breeding in grass and behind hammocks, but less freely than
it is above.
(d) In the angle between the creek and the branch, left
side of both, about 250 yards from the house, is a meadow, dry now,
but in which there has recently been pools. The ground is still
wet; glazed and cracked, but there is no water standing. This
place should have been physically well fit for breeding, say seven
days ago.
(6) CARSWELL'S. Small pool, on Mr. Pyatts land, I
think, close to box for minnows. Breeding freely. About one doxen
and half Anopheles taken from it. 100 yards from the Carswell
house.
(b) The branch going down from this place is not
breeding sufficiently to be of sanitary importance. Many Dixa
larvae.
(c) The main creek running between this place and Bost's
breeding moderately opposite this house, probably one-quarter or
one-third of a mile distant.
(d) This house is about one-third of a mile from the
places that were breeding so freely on Mr. Bost's land last year.
In his spring branch and the marsh between the hog pen and the bridge.
(See report of Aug. 21st, Page 4.) These two and the creek are of
greater importance in affecting this place than the pool within
the 100 yards unless it was generally producing more freely than
when we examined it--which I judge it is in wet weather.
(7) HOUSE OF RAYMOND LEWIS: About 200 yards or 250
yards from Nebo higher up the valley. No one in the house when
we called.
(a) A stream runs from behind the house and then across
the road and railroad from 20 to 50 yards distant from the house,--
breeding Anopheles freely or profusely; all sizes of larvae and
pupae & in great number. The only place that was not breeding in at is a piece of
about 25 feet long where ducks evidently bathe. It was breeding
-6-
most freely where just crossing the road. At a pool dammed up
just below the railroad, we took 60 to 75 larvae and 15 pupae.
(8) MR. AND MRS. EDWARDS' HOUSE ON THE SOUTH SIDE
OF THE RIVER.
This is the place (2) Culverson's Creek on Page 5 of
the report of July 18, 1922.
(a) Small marsh inside the pasture breeding in July
is dry now, absolutely.
(b) The branch running from the spring, breeding
slightly in July, is breeding freely now, all sizes; from
just above the road crossing up to the fence at the spring, in-
creasing as one goes. up.
(c) The small marshy places about the spring is
breeding freely or profusely now, all sizes and pupae, as is
the old abandoned spring. This place is about 100 yards dis-
tance from the house of J. W. Edwards, deceased.
The joint production of (b) & (c)
is large & is close to the house
mentioned
(8) GRANT EDWARDS. No one at home. No water found
close enough to this house to affect it. Mr. George Whetstine
states that Edwards has recently moved here.
(9) GEORGE WHETSTINE'S HOUSE: On the hill not far
from Grant Edwards. The only water close by is not breeding and
I think would not breed in wet weather. Young woman in house
sick. The old woman says with malaria. Mr. Whetstine says had
malaria and new baby.
(10) _________GLASS. (colored). Five families live
in this settlement; all colored; on the ridge going down to-
wards the creek that flows into the pond at Curtis' place. There
is probably 300 yards distance from the one highest on the hill
to the one closest to the spring.
(a) This is the place marked “ (3) Station X ” on
page 5 of the report of July 18th. All this section was breed-
ing in July. A few are found in the creek now, but the marshes
-7-
are dried up, with cracked glazed bottoms of the old pools.
This creek goes down and empties into the pond just above what
I am told is the old Curtis place, roughly, a mile from the
spring. All of this bottom is marshy. The lower part is one
big marsh. We did not go into it.
(11) THE CURTIS PLACE.
The house has just been torn down; chimney still
standing; said to be the place George Whetstine lived last
year. Is about 50 yards from the edge of the pond and close
to, say 300 yards from the lower part of the marsh on the last
creek mentioned. The spring branch just below his house, 40
yards distant, is marshy, but not breeding of no sanitary im-
portance. Where there is no blood supply for the Anopheles
they are rarely found breeding and as this house is abandoned
and there is no stock in the immediate vacinity we would not
have expected to find breeding here now, although it might
have been present when the house was occupied.

The pond by my measure is 6 or 7 feet below the
ordinary (top of spillway) grade.
(1) The Club House is screened with #12 wire.
Chimneys not screened and door loose. No Anopheles found inside.
(No complaint made by guests.) Bath houses not screened; cool
and moist. No Anopheles found. Two good size spider webs on
the mens' side. No Anopheles found on them. Small house on
the hill examined by Dr. Boldridge. (He reports none found.)
Evidently no winged Anopheles in neighborhood of Club House;
#12 wire would not exclude them.
(2) Bight at the left of the mouth of Mill Creek
(Marked (2) on Page one of July report)
(a) A few baby larvae in stranded alga in seepage - not developed Sept 1922
from the hill about 6 feet above the present pond level. The
water quite cool here; cooler than the surface of the pond,
hence it is seepage. Nothing found in the bulrushes dead,
or alive, on either bank of this bight. Many minnows seen
along the bank in shore water.
(3) Mouth of stream about 1,000 feet below the Curtis
house. No breeding in pond water. Some breeding in a branch
from a spring about 20 yards above the pond flowing through
grass in which the larvae (a) above are found.
(4) Mouth of creek that comes from Glass's spring
emptying in above the Curtis house.
(a) No breeding found in bight of pond or in the
backwater of creek. Many minnows seen in edges of pond in
shallow water.
(b) A flat on the left bank of the creek has evidently
been dry sometime, had young grass on it as long as one's finger.
Many bulrushes in clumps are there and when the water was, say,
-2-
four to five feet higher than at present, these bulrushes
had formed a place physically suitable for Anopheles breeding.
There is however, no evidence of alga having been among them.
A few patches of dried alga, greenish spots on the ground are
seen on the right side of the creek in the open.
(5) MOUTH OF TWO LOG CREEK.
This is a bight of Mill creek (Marked 1, Page one of
the July report).
(a) The pond here and the back-water are absolutely
free from breeding. A fair number of minnows on the edge in
shore water.
(b) Going up the creek on land about one-third of a mile
from the pond, a good sized marshy place was found breeding
fairly. This is the place marked (1) on Page 4 of the July report.
It is breeding now, much more freely than it was in July. The
creek above this forks and both forks, the right especially, have
a wide marshy bottoms. The creek itself was not breeding at or
near its mouth.
(6) Bight 250 below the last one (nearer the pond),
Two streams going in, both small, but (the larger one is to the
right), join before reaching the back-water. Neither stream is
breeding. There are two pools in the valley of the larger
stream both scummed, one with red water, the other might have
bred two weeks ago. A fair amount of trash and some alga, of
unknown species, about the head of the bight. This was dipped
very carefully, over 100 dips made, but nothing found.
(7) Off the mouth of Culvertson's Creek, (see #3, Page
1, July report). This is a long bight.
(a) Banks on the right side is steep and cut by waves
from its commencement to the old road--showing that there has
been much wave action there and breeding impossible.
(b) The old road is sunken and should have made still
water and hence given protection from the wave. Some stranded floatage
-3-
near the present water line in this old road which might have
given protection from fish. There is then a possibility
of there having been breeding in the old road before the pond
reached its present level. There is a school of minnows in
the road and at present it is absolutely free from breeding.
(c) Beyond the road the ridge showed wave action by
the floatage at some places.
(d) No breeding in back-water, breeding in the creek
itself well above the pond, but not of sanitary importance,
probably washed down from above. (This is the creek that runs
from Mr. Edward's house, Page 6 of the 1st part of this report. Land Breeding of Anopheles mosquitos
(e) On the left hand side of the bight the banks
had been well cleared up to the floatwage line but sprouts had
come up from many stumps and brushes. Now the sprouts are
dead. Sprouts are also standing in the creek bed.
(f) On the left bank beyond the high water, the water here
has been on the grass and up to, and possibly in, the broom-sage
edge. If this was so, protection would have been given against
the fish and as there is considerably flat ground, wave action
would have been impeded, although, there is a long stretch of
water from this place southeast and the waves would have
bad a long sweep.
(8) Bights to the east of 7 bears north by west looking
up.
(a) Bight going out to the west side--negative. Runs
to main road and beyond the road is a large pond of clear water;
bank,
not scummed; with grassy except that it has no
alga (Frog broth) is apparently an ideal place for Anopheles
quadrimaculatus. In it were many Culex and a few very small Ano-
pheles. One only full grown and two or three half grown, were
taken. Two of us dipped 15 minutes.
One larva developed & un Sept 23- was A. punctepennis, like all others
found in this section
-4-
(b) Went up to the head of the bight one-half mile
or more from the Edwards bight #7. The banks show wave-action
nearly to the end. A full wave action too much for breeding
to have been possible, except for about 200 feet, from the end
where there is a slight bend which shelters the bank from wave-
action. The bank is steep on the west side and precipitors on
the east side. Evidently there has been much wave action in
this bight and breeding, except at the very end bhad, I think,
been impossible.

div1.p:
No Anopheles larvae then were found in the pond
water, or, except possibly, those named in (a) of #2 Page 1 of
this paper; none other found in any water in any way connected with
the pond. These arewere absolutely of no sanitary importance

Nevertheless, with regard to the investigation of our
pond breeding, a criticism somewhat similar to that of the land
breeding might be made at least for this years survey, i.e. that
it was not made at the best time.

To determine whether a pond produces Anopheles, very
obviously, the examination of the pond should be made when the
conditions are most favorable for such production. To examine
a pond in January and find no Anopheles would be little evidence
that it was not breeding in August.

The conditions which controls production in ponds are:
(1) Temperature
(2) Protection against wave action,
(3) Protection against fish.

It is also true that access to a sufficient blood
supply-- in this country to men and domestic animal-- tends to
affect production.

About Bridgewater, the temperature conditions would gen-
erally be best suited for breeding, from about August 15th to
September 15th. Protection against wave-action depends on the
-5-
configuration of the banks & does not change. It locality and is greatest in the ends of twisted bights of the
pond; especially if they have rafts of logs lodged in them.
Protection against fish is given by the fine stuff-floatage-
washed down into the ends of such bights and by grass on the
waters edge when the water is in such grass. Broomstraw and
bulrushes would be especially good.

My first survey, Aug. 16th to 22nd inclusive, of 1921,
was made at the proper time of year. It was made off the south
bank of Catawba pond only, from the dam to a point up the pond
one and one-quarter miles from the Bost house. There are a number of
twisted bights in this area, some of which have rafts of logs
protecting the ends and banks against wave action. In most of
these bights there was lots of fine floatage and in a few, grass
on the waters edge, giving protection against fish.

All the conditions then of this survey then were favor-
able for breeding Anopheles and the examination made at that
time was sufficient. No anopheles were found and it is fair to say
that none existed in the area examined and it is reasonable to
claim the same of similar shores adjacent to those examined. I
have given the probable alternative reasons for this in my re-
port of Aug. 1921.

For the north side of the Catawba pond and of Paddy
Creek as far as examined the water in the bights above the mouth
of streams, is shallow. There is no shallow water on the part of
the south bank examined. The water in the bights on the north side
then should be warmer and indeed is warmer, than that examined in
1921.

The survey of July of this year was negative. No breed-
ing was found in the pond, although some of the water seemed quite
warm, Yet as it would have been warmer later in the season, I could
not say that the most favorable temperature for breeding in this
section had been reached and hence it was proper to come back
later in the summer. The other two conditions at this time-pro-
tection against fish and against wave-action-were ideal

The surveys just finished were made the proper time
of the year and there was of course the same protection against
wave-action as always exists. The pond, however, had fallen from
6 1/2 to 7 feet and there was an absolute absence of floatage on the w
water edge and except in one place no protection against fish.
That there was no breeding in the pond was true, but I wish much,
I could have examined it before it was lowered at all, when there
would have been, or might have been protection against fish, if
there is ever such protection. Had this been the case all condi-
tions for Anopheles production has been the best possible in this
section of the lake as they were on the south side last year.

Frankly, ifsince there was no breeding up to July 18th, and
as all of August, after the 3rd was cold, I profoundly doubt if t
there was any production of Anopheles even on the north side of
the lake between that time and the date in the latter part of
August (Aug 29th) when the pond was lowered. Still I have only my
opinion of this, and if I could have made the survey in latter part
of August, I feel quite sure I would have had this as an observed
facts.

I have to add that the north side of the Catawba lake
and Paddy Creek section where I had opportunity to examine them,
were well cleared and banks remarkably free from logs and all
heavy trash. Indeed this part of the lake showed the cleanest
banks of any new pond that I have ever examined.

Very respectfully,
H. R. Carter
MEMO #1.

I think it will be necessary to determine the distance
of the residents of the nearest plaintiff to the nearest part
of the lake-- and if it is practical-- to plat them on the map.
I note that every one of them to whom I spoke gave the distance
as less than the facts.
Respectfully,
MEMO #2.

When all these Bridgewater suits are settled, I
would like much to have a survey made without any expense to
yourself
(1) Of the lake the surveying had better started on it
from Aug. 1st & last to Sept. 30th and maybe for more than one year.
(2) At the same time a survey of the pools in the
old bed of the Catawba and of the pools cut off by the company
road.

This would determine whether the pond-breeding
mosquito (A. Quad) is breeding in this section, and if not why
not.

This investigation would be extremly valuable from a
scientific standpoint and would go in with my general investi-
gation begun in 1913 of the “Effect of Impounding Water of the
Incidents of Malaria.”

Also, when all the suits are over, I would ask per-
mission to use my reports to you as data in some investigation.
This, by-the-way is pretty good evidence that I consider such
reports as scientifically accurate.

Respectfully,
H. R. Carter
